natural solution: Factoring a $2$ out of the second term gives $2(x+3)(x-3)=2(x^2-3^2)=\boxed{2x^2-18}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x - 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = P x * Q x"
shows  "R x = 2 * x^2 - 18"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand $(x+3)(2x-6)$. The final Answer is 2x^2-18
 ### Proof
 Factoring a $2$ out of the second term gives $2(x+3)(x-3)=2(x^2-3^2)=\boxed{2x^2-18}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x + 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x - 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = P x * Q x"
shows  "R x = 2 * x^2 - 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given the functions $P(x) = x + 3$, $Q(x) = 2x - 6$, and $R(x) = P(x) \cdot Q(x)$, find an expression for $R(x)$. The final answer is $R(x) = 2x^2 - 18$.
